Triggering Event: A middle-aged man, alone in his study after another long day at the hospital, notices a photo of his late wife among the medical texts. His eyes harden as he remembers her laughter, now silenced by cancer. He clenches his jaw, resentment rising like bile in his throat. Why did she have to leave him? The house feels emptier than ever, echoing with bitterness.
Generated Assessment: He can't stand it anymore! She's gone for so long now, but I still feel her presence everywhere. Every time I see a picture of her, I get angry all over again. It's been months since she passed away, but the pain is still there. We were meant to spend our lives together; instead, we're just memories now. She never told me about her illness until it was too late. I remember feeling numb when I first heard the news, like my heart had turned into ice. Now, every day feels like a struggle. Her smile haunts me, reminding me of what I've lost. I keep looking through old photos, hoping to find some comfort, but they only make things worse. I know she loved me deeply, but why did she have to leave? Why couldn't she fight? I try to push those thoughts aside, but they linger, making me resentful. I miss her laugh, her warmth, everything about her. I wish I could turn back time and be there for her, but that's impossible. All I'm left with are tears and anger. If only she had told me sooner, maybe things would have been different. But now, I'm left to pick up the pieces, and it's almost unbearable. I look around our home, remembering how she'd decorate each room, and it hurts even more. Everything feels hollow without her. I don't want to think about this anymore, but the memories keep coming back

Triggering Event: She stood in front of her latest canvas, brush trembling slightly as she dabbed at the paint. Her partner walked in, glanced briefly at the blank space before them, and said, "Still nothing new this week." The room seemed to shrink around her, the weight of his words pressing down like a physical force. She felt her cheeks flush with heat, shame coiling in her stomach as she turned away from him and her unfinished art.
Generated Assessment: She couldn’t help but feel like she was drowning in her own sorrow when he spoke those harsh words. “Still nothing new this week” echoed through the air, each syllable piercing her heart like a knife. It wasn't just the pain of her failed attempt that hit her so hard; it was the way he looked at her - with an expression that seemed to say, “You’re holding me back.” Like I’m the one who’s dragging you down. Every time she tried to create something beautiful, every moment she poured her soul into her art, he found fault in it. His criticisms cut deep, making her question whether she was even good enough to share her talents with the world. And now, standing there, facing him with tears welling up in her eyes, she realized she had been comparing herself to him all along. He didn’t know what it took to make her feel alive, to give her wings. But she did. Every late night spent perfecting her craft, every early morning that dawned before the sun, every struggle she faced alone. Those moments were hers, and no one else could understand how precious they were. Yet, whenever she opened her heart, showing him everything, he would bring it crashing down. The memories flooded her mind, images of broken dreams and shattered hopes. Why did he have to be the one to tear them apart? Why did he get to see her at her weakest? She felt trapped, stuck between two worlds:

Triggering Event: "Under the harsh fluorescent lights of the hospital, he watched as the doctor delivered the news to the tearful family in the waiting room. Another patient lost. He felt a pang of misery, remembering his own mother's final moments. His phone buzzed - his girlfriend's message read 'We need to talk.' He felt the weight of the day crush him."
Generated Assessment: It is clear that one has made an error in judgment. The fact that there are patients who have died in the hospital does not necessarily mean that death will occur at all times. In fact, it is far more likely that many people live healthy lives, free from illness. It is simply a matter of perspective. One can choose to focus on the positive aspects of life, rather than dwelling on the negative. Life is full of ups and downs, and the former often outweighs the latter. To say that death is inevitable because it has occurred before is to overlook the vast majority of people who live long, healthy lives. The truth is, death is not always present; it is merely an occasional occurrence. Those who dwell on this aspect tend to forget about the abundance of life. One must remember to appreciate each moment, rather than focusing solely on the negative. Life is precious and fleeting. We should cherish every second, not let the fear of death dictate our actions. Death may be a part of life, but it is certainly not the whole of it. We must learn to appreciate the beauty in life, even when faced with adversity. Our goal should be to make the most of each moment, regardless of whether we face challenges or not. I am reminded that my friend told me once that she had been given a new lease on life after her near-death experience. She said that now she was determined to enjoy herself, to love, to laugh, and to live fully.

Triggering Event: A forgotten anniversary reminder pops up on her phone, buried under unanswered messages from friends she hasn't seen in months. She glances at it briefly before silencing her phone and returning to chopping vegetables, alone in her empty kitchen.
Generated Assessment: Ugh, why does my brain even bother? I can see them all so clearly—my friend's beautiful wedding photos, the couple celebrating their first anniversary, each one flashing through my mind like a movie reel. It’s as if they’re trying to remind me that I’m missing out. But what does it mean when I just delete the notification without looking? Is it guilt? Or maybe I'm just tired of seeing how perfect everything looks right now. Maybe it's just another day, but somehow it feels like every time someone else is getting married or having fun, I'm back here, cooking dinner for no one. It doesn’t feel fair, but I know I have no reason to be upset. Still, it makes me wonder why everyone keeps moving forward while I stay behind. Why can't this day go by without making me think about all the things I don't have?

As she walks up to her house, she notices that the backdoor is slightly ajar, although she's certain she had locked it before leaving. She feels a prickling sensation at the base of her spine, her heart pounding in her chest as she quietly enters her own home, each creak of the floorboards echoing like thunder in her ears.
